qas.question: What phrase has been called a misnomer?
What has the 'war on terror' been used as an excuse for?

answers.text: to pursue long-standing policy/military objectives, reduce civil liberties, and infringe upon human rights

qas.question: Which other misnamed 'war' has 'war on terror' been compared to?
What is the likely fate of the 'war on terror'?

answers.text: it is unlikely international terrorism can be brought to an end by military means

qas.question: What is another name for War on Drugs?
What is most likely to be ended by military means?

plausible_answers.text: long-standing policy/military objectives, reduce civil liberties, and infringe upon human rights

qas.question: What has the War on Drugs been used as an excuse for?
What term is appropriate for one with no identifiable enemy?

context: Criticism of the <b4_0>War on Terror<b4_0/> addresses the issues, morality, efficiency, economics, and other questions surrounding the <a0_0>War on Terror<a0_0/> and made against the phrase itself, calling it a misnomer. The notion of a "war" against "terrorism" has proven highly contentious, with critics charging that it has been exploited by participating governments <a1_0>to pursue <b6_0>long-standing policy/military objectives, reduce civil liberties, and infringe upon human rights<b6_0/><a1_0/>. It is argued that the term <b7_0>war<b7_0/> is not appropriate in this context (as in <a2_0><b5_0>War on Drugs<b5_0/><a2_0/>), since there is no identifiable enemy, and that <a3_0>it is unlikely international terrorism can be brought to an end by military means<a3_0/>.
